comment_text:
Kevin Gaskin. You are welcome to search for the Bill of Rights, the American Constitution and the Declaration of Independence, but you will not find anything about the "separation of Church and State" contained in any of them.

Thomas Jefferson wrote a letter to the Danbury Baptist Association in 1802 to respond to a letter from them, asking why he would not proclaim national days of fasting and thanksgiving, as Washington and Adams had done before him. . The letter contains the phrase "wall of separation between Church and State", which led to the erroneous "handrail" for the Establishment Clause (US Constitution, Bill of Rights, Amendment I, Article III) that we use today.

"Why do I have religious freedom ...?" The answer lies in the congressional documents that relate to our Constitution as we know it today. The drafting process of the First Amendment made the intentions of the Founders abundantly clear; Before approving the final wording, the First Amendment had a dozen different iterations and lengthy discussions.

"We do not want in America what we had in Britain: we do not want a denomination to lead the Nation, we will not all be Catholics, nor Anglicans, nor any other denomination, we want the principles of God, but we do not want a denomination to lead the nation. "

This intention was well understood, as evidence by the court decisions after the First Amendment. In 1799, the court declared: "By our form of government, the Christian religion is the established religion; and all sects and denominations of Christians are placed on the same footing. "

It must be realized that our founding fathers strove to attain "freedom of religion" because of the oppressive authority of the Roman Catholic Church. It was not only Great Britain but most of Europe that fell under the awesome authority of Roman Catholicism. Our founding fathers undertook to recognize the many denominations of Christianity. Moreover, they intended to recognize each denomination equally, rather than granting the power of control to any denomination. Here lies the erroneous interpretation of the imprudent "shorthand" known as the "separation of Church and State".

A more specific statement is likely to "separate denominations from church and state." Such an interpretation is fully supported by Congressional documents in reference to the statement, "We do not want in America what we had in Great Britain: we do not want a denomination that directs the Nation. We will not be all Catholics, nor Anglicans, nor any other denomination. We want the principles of God, but we do not want a denomination to lead the Nation. "

As for the statement, "most of our founding fathers were agnostics," that's just not true. It is a general statement proclaimed by those who oppose religion in general. Yes, there were agnostics at that time, but they were not as prevalent as was claimed. Thomas Paine was an Anglo-American political activist, philosopher, political and revolutionary theorist. Although he is considered one of our founding fathers, he was shunned for his known agnostic beliefs.

John Adams is another one wrongly accused of being agnostic. Yet, here is a quote from President Adams in reference to Thomas Paine; "The Christian religion is, first of all the religions that have prevailed or existed in ancient or modern times, the religion of wisdom, virtue, fairness and humanity, let the Blackguard Paine say what he wants. " I believe you will agree about Mr. Paine are more than enough to dispel all the claims of his agnostic beliefs.

comment_text:
Q1) Are GDP data faked?

- Yes they are. They are not precise. They are trafficked to promote a lie.

Q2) Can you prove that GDP data is faked?

- Until January 2015, the Indian economy had grown since the mid-1980s. And then the magic happened. The Central Bureau of Statistics (CSO) has changed the way it calculates GDP by saying that it is necessary to do so by taking into account global practices. As a result, India has moved ahead of China and has become the fastest growing economy. In 2013-14, our economy grew by 6.9%, rather than 4.7%, which CSO data showed earlier. Even the country's chief economic adviser, Arvind Subramanian, said: "I am intrigued by the new GDP growth figures.The revised figures show that GDP growth went from 4.7% to 5.1% in 2012-2013 and 5% to 6.9% in 2013-2014, which means an acceleration in GDP growth of 1.9 percentage points in 2013-14, just by comparing the new figures over time. " also said that "these figures, especially the acceleration in 2013-14, are at odds with other features of the macroeconomy." Almost all economic experts, working in or out of government (including Mr. Raghuram Rajan) , questioned the GDP figures as they found that the realities on the ground reflected a completely opposite picture According to R Nagraj, an independent member of the subcommittee who reviewed the new methodology for estimating output, adopted central organization Stastal differed significantly from the report finalized by the subcommittee in September 2014.

Q3) What about the latest GDP data released after demonetization?

- They are also messed up. While the performance of some sectors has been better than their performance in previous quarters, the huge improvement in private consumption (almost doubled) seems very doubtful in the context of the currency crisis during the demonetization. It seems that the CSO has not been able to map the demonetisation effect in its data. The government and RBI have also said (as do some of their sensible critics) that the effect of demonetization can be mapped in the longer term. In addition, the OSC downgraded the 2015-2016 third quarter estimates by 0.3 percentage points to 6.9% from 7.2% previously, resulting in a significant improvement in the third quarter figures. quarter of 2016-2017. For those who do not find this surprising, the OSC has revised the estimates of the UP for the first and second quarters of 2015-2016. This downward revision of the third quarter of 2015-2016 helped to limit the effect of demonetization in figures.

Q4) I am not able to understand anything. Why?

- You will not be able to have it. You are neither a statistician nor an economist. Whenever reports and claims like these surface, a little more on the Internet than Facebook and Twitter, and read basic things and what the experts have to say about them.

Q5) But Modi Ji says the experts do not know anything. Do not you think he's right?

- After Hindutva, the best tactic of Modi ji is misinformation. He convinced people by believing that experts do not know anything. He disinforms people who know nothing but to believe him. They do not have enough time or will to discover the truth. And when the experts question his claims and he, people never understand what the experts say because they are not educated enough to understand.
label: CAG

comment_text:
What you need to know about the President of Turkey, Recap Tayyip Erdogan:

The Turkish economy between 2002 and 2012 led to a 64% growth in real GDP and a 43% increase in GDP per capita.

Erdoƒüan inherited a debt of $ 23.5 billion to the IMF, which was reduced to $ 0.9 billion in 2012. He decided not to sign a new agreement. Turkey's debt to the IMF was declared fully paid and it announced that the IMF could borrow from Turkey.

In 2010, Turkey's five-year credit default swaps traded at a record low of 1.17%, lower than that of nine EU member states and Russia.

In 2002, the Turkish central bank had reserves of $ 26.5 billion. This amount reached $ 92.2 billion in 2011. During Erdoƒüan's term. Inflation rose from 32% to 9.0% in 2004.

Under the Erdoƒüan government, the number of airports in Turkey increased from 26 to 50.

Between 2002 and 2011, 13500 km of motorways were built.

For the first time in Turkish history, high-speed rail lines were built and the country's high-speed rail service began in 2009. In 8 years, 1076 km of railways have been built and 5449 km of renewed railways.

Erdogan has invested more in the health system than any other predecessor. As part of the reforms, the "Green Card" program, which offers free health benefits to the poor.

Erdoƒüan has increased spending on education from 7.5 billion lire in 2002 to 34 billion in 2011, the largest share of the national budget allocated to a ministry, and the number of universities in Turkey having almost doubled from 98 in 2002 to 186 in October 2012.

comment_text:
Cow in Hinduism:

Eat beef (Mata cow) allowed in Hinduism.
The Rigveda (10/8/13) states: "On the occasion of the marriage of a girl, oxen and cows are slaughtered.
Rigveda (6/17/1) states that "Indra used to eat the meat of the cow, the calf, the horse and the buffalo."
Manusmriti (chapter 5 / verse 30) says: "He is not guilty of eating meat of edible animals, for Brahma has created both eaters and edibles."
Maharishi Yagyavalkya says in Shatpath Brahmin (3/1/2/21): "I eat beef because it is very sweet and delicious."
Apastamb Grihsutram (1/3/10) says, "The cow should be slaughtered on the arrival of a guest, on the occasion of 'Shraddha' ancestors and on the occasion of a wedding."
Vashistha Dharmasutra (11/34) writes: "If a Brahman refuses to eat the meat offered to him on the occasion of 'Shraddha' or worship, he goes to hell.

http://indianexpress.com/article/india/fatwa-issued-against-reality-singing-star-nahid-afrin-by-42-clerics-4569825/

Dear Indian,
I'm sorry to write that your reporters are there to misinterpret the events and present them in a distorted way just to make sensational headlines. The news about future singer Nahid Afreen has been prepared without proper research and investigation. It was very sad to see that your journalists do not even know the difference between fatwa and call.
A fatwa is a non-binding legal opinion issued only by a qualified lawyer (Mufti) at the request of a person who does not understand the religious guidelines while the booklet that is distributed and presented as Fatwa is only a paper copy an appeal signed by 46 men who believe in religious practices. The merit of the appeal can be discussed on many points and in many dimensions, but first and foremost, an appeal can not be called a legal opinion (Fatwa).
We are waiting for an apology from you for such an error

comment_text:
Dear Indian,
I'm sorry to write that your reporters are there to misinterpret the events and present them in a distorted way just to make sensational headlines. The news about future singer Nahid Afreen has been prepared without proper research and investigation. It was very sad to see that your journalists do not even know the difference between fatwa and call.
A fatwa is a non-binding legal opinion issued only by a qualified lawyer (Mufti) at the request of a person who does not understand the religious guidelines while the booklet that is distributed and presented as Fatwa is only a paper copy an appeal signed by 46 men who believe in religious practices. The merit of the appeal can be discussed on many points and in many dimensions, but first and foremost, an appeal can not be called a legal opinion (Fatwa).
We are waiting for an apology from you for such an error.

Dear Indian,
I'm sorry to write that your reporters are there to misinterpret the events and present them in a distorted way just to make sensational headlines. The news about future singer Nahid Afreen has been prepared without proper research and investigation. It was very sad to see that your journalists do not even know the difference between fatwa and call.
A fatwa is a non-binding legal opinion issued only by a qualified lawyer (Mufti) at the request of a person who does not understand the religious guidelines while the booklet that is distributed and presented as Fatwa is only a paper copy an appeal signed by 46 men who believe in religious practices. The merit of the appeal can be discussed on many points and in many dimensions, but first and foremost, an appeal can not be called a legal opinion (Fatwa).
